sub_topic: Numerical differentiation and integration using finite difference methods
message_1: Suppose you have a function f(x) = 2x^3 - 5x^2 + 3x - 1. Using the forward difference formula with a step size of h = 0.5, compute the approximate values of the first derivative of f at x = 1.5 and x = 2.5. Also, use the central difference formula with the same step size to compute the approximate value of the second derivative of f at x = 2.
message_2:
To compute the approximate values of the first derivative of f at x = 1.5 and x = 2.5 using the forward difference formula, we use the formula:

f'(x) ≈ (f(x + h) - f(x)) / h

where h = 0.5.

For x = 1.5:
f(1.5) = 2(1.5)^3 - 5(1.5)^2 + 3(1.5) - 1 = -1.875
f(1.5 + 0.5) = f(2) = 2(2)^3 - 5(2)^2 + 3(2) - 1 = -7
f'(1.5) ≈ (f(2) - f(1.5)) / 0.5 = (-7 - (-1.875)) / 0.5 = -10.25

For x = 2.5:
f(2.5) = 2(2.5)^3 - 5(2.5)^2 + 3(2.5) - 1 = -12.625
f(2.5 + 0.5) = f(3) = 2(3)^3 - 5(3)^2 + 3(3) - 1 = -19
f'(2.5) ≈ (f(3) - f(2.5)) / 0.5 = (-19 - (-12.625)) / 0.5 = -12.75

Now, to compute the approximate value of the second derivative of f at x = 2 using the central difference formula, we use the formula:

f''(x) ≈ (f(x + h) - 2f(x) + f(x - h)) / h^2

For x = 2:
f(2 - 0.5) = f(1.5) = -1.875
f(2) = -7
f(2 + 0.5) = f(2.5) = -12.625
f''(2) ≈ (f(2.5) - 2f(2) + f(1.5)) / 0.5^2 = (-12.625 - 2(-7) + (-1.875)) / 0.25 = -10

So, the approximate values of the first derivative of f at x = 1.5 and x = 2.5 are -10.25 and -12.75, respectively, and the approximate value of the second derivative of f at x = 2 is -10.
